bibl.title: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Laura Armistead Carter, September 25, 1930

div1.p: Frost explains that he has omitted the footnotes in question, and instead included an Editor's Note discussing the implications of more recent research.

div1.head: Letter from Wade Hampton Frost to Laura Armistead Carter, September 25, 1930
div1.opener:
THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
SCHOOL OF HYGIENE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
615 NORTH WOLFE STREET
DEPARTMENT OF EPIDEMIOLOGY
BALTIMORE, MD.
September 25, 1930.
Miss Laura A. Carter,
The Westmoreland Apts.,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Miss Laura:
div1.p:
When I saw you the day before yesterday, I
had not seen your note of September 22d, enclosing
a page from your father's manuscript, which I am
herewith returning.

I have prepared a note to be inserted in
Section I, noting the more important facts that
have been developed by experimental studies with
yellow fever since 1925. In this note, I have said
that the new facts make no change in the writer's
fundamental conception of the epidemiology of
yellow fever, but merely confirm previous inferences
except as regards the agency of leptospira in
causation of the disease, it being now definitely
proven that leptospira infection is quite different
from yellow fever, whereas when the MS. was written
leptospira was tentatively accepted as the probable
specific cause of the disease.

I believe that with this note, which I think
is absolutely exact, it will be quite all right to
omit the reference to leptospira which appears on
page 5 of the re-typed MS. It will also be quite
proper to omit the foot-note which appears on that
page, my plan being to substitute for it an editor's
note of about two pages, noting recent contributions
to experimental knowledge of yellow fever.

The second foot-note to which your letter refers
is incorporated in the text on page 6. The meaning
of this statement is clear enough and since it alludes
to a possibility which may now be experimentally tested,
and mentions it only as a possibility, not as a
conclusion, I see no reason at all for omitting it.
On the contrary, I rather think it should be included.

The note which I have prepared for insertion
is not yet in a shape which is entirely satisfactory
to me, hence the draft which I am sending you is
subject to revision. As noted above, I think the
best place to insert it is on page 5 of the re-typed
MS., replacing the note which is at present found there.

I hope you will take care of yourself and get
back into good shape.
div1.closer:
With best regards,
Sincerely yours, W. H. Frost W.A.F.
W. H. Frost
